all_paragraphs: •How do we build an Effective Decision Tree?
Before we begin, i’m assuming you understand the concept of Regression and Classification, minimally at a high level. If not, here’s a quick summary:
Before we dive into the details, let’s start by understanding how we make decisions with two really simple examples…

Left > Based on the color of the sky, we decide whether or not to go out and play a game (Categorical decision). Right > Based on the waist size of a cat, we decide on rough estimate of its weight (Numerical decision). On a side note, that cat needs some serious help dieting!

> Assessing the risk of a patient getting infected by a disease that elderly are more prone to. The above is a hypothetical mental model (albeit a simplified one) of a doctor as he looks through your personal/health records to assess your risk of contracting a disease…
As with most algorithms, we are likely to encounter a couple of jargon. Here’s a visual representation to help us go through the terms…
Root Node: The entire sample or population of data
Splitting: process of dividing a node into two or more sub-nodes
Decision Node: A sub-node with other sub-nodes. They have arrows pointing to them and arrows pointing away from them.
Leaf/ Terminal Node: Nodes with no sub-nodes (no further split). They have arrows pointing to them but no arrows pointing away from them.
Parent/Child Node: A node divided into sub-nodes is called a parent node of sub-nodes whereas sub-nodes are the children of a parent node.
Sub-tree/Branch: A sub-section of the tree
Now that that’s out of the way, let’s look at how a decision tree helps us to predict the outcome of a problem!

This imaginary data set describes how a patient’s age as well as common viral symptoms e.g. breathing difficulty and chest pain are used to predict if a person has been infected with the Covid-19 disease.
1. The entire patient data set is fed into the root node.
2. A question is asked about the patient and the data set is split/partitioned based on whether the answer is true or false.

3. At each split, the algorithm tries to ensure the patients in the resulting partitions are as homogeneous as possible (i.e. all virus-positive or virus-negative on each of the sub-nodes). If a sub-node isn’t well-separated, a further question is asked to further split the data set.
4. The process continues until no more patients can be split or a stopping criteria is met.

In order to obtain questions, we iterate over every value that appears in each row of a predictor column. Each value becomes a potential candidate for a threshold used to partition the data into distinct subsets:
The best questions reduce uncertainty the most and lead to the purest leaf nodes.
What does it mean to reduce uncertainty? To understand this, let us look at the following 2 examples at the leaf nodes of our decision tree:

On the left side, each leaf node contains a mixture of individuals with and without Covid-19 i.e. impure. If we were to classify individuals in the the left leaf-node as positive, the probability of being classified correctly is only 50% since it only contains 25/50 covid-positive individuals.

On the right side, each leaf node of the decision tree are completely homogeneous (50/50 covid-positive and 48/48 covid-negative) i.e. pure. If we were to classify individuals in the the left leaf-node as positive, the probability of being classified correctly is 100% since it only contains covid-positive individuals.
Therefore, having a purer node increases the chance of being classified correctly and reduces uncertainty in the decision outcome.
